title: MOAA hosts Air Force troops for golf tournament
text:
2:00 am - October 13, 2015 MOAA hosts Air Force troops for golf tournament Dick Weber, Bob Vannie, Airman Spencer Dingman and Kirby Edeus pause on their way to the tee box. 
By MARY ELIADES 
Staff writer 
Thirteen troops from the Little Rock Air Force Base were guests of the Hot Springs Village Military Officers Association of America chapter for a recent golf tournament and dinner. 
The tournament was wholly sponsored by MOAA, and the airmen were joined by 45 MOAA members and friends – “very patriotic civilians,” said MOAA president John Weidert. 
“We do this every year to honor our servicemen,” said Don Dreiling, who emceed the event. “We appreciate them coming over here for the day.” 
“This contingent spanned numerous war fighting career fields,” said Weidert. “These selfless young military folks are fine representatives of the ‘best and brightest’ in today’s armed forces.” 
Golfers played a scramble at Cortez Golf Course, with plenty of prizes and fellowship. 
Cash prizes were awarded to the top three teams, and Dreiling said his four-person scramble team – which won with a score of 59 – gave their winnings to the airman in their group. 
Dreiling’s team included Kenneth Dugas, Richard Hollis and Jeff Brewer, USAF. 
In addition to prizes for the top three teams, golfers competed for closest to the pin, longest putt and closest to the line, as well as a shot at a hole-in-one on No. 17. 
Golfers enjoyed a prime rib banquet, catered by the Home Plate Café, at the Coronado Center after their rounds. 
Maj. Gen. Tom Arwood addressed the troops, thanking them for their service and for taking the time to travel to the Village to spend a day on the course with appreciative Village residents. 
Emcee Dreiling also thanked Dick Hoepner, who has been organizing the event “for 200 years.” 
The airmen joined Dreiling in the tongue-in-cheek “Air Force pledge,” and then were asked to introduce themselves and indicate their hometowns and jobs at the air base. 
Chief Ralph Babcock told the gathering how much the troops enjoyed the outing, saying, “We have never been treated this well at any event we’ve gone to.” 
The airmen received hats, balls and tees, and one lucky (or skilled) golfer won a PING golf bag for his closest putt on a specially set-up green. 
Weidert said, “As we all know, the United States armed forces are the first ones called upon to defend this great nation of ours against armed aggression throughout the world. 
“Our armed forces do so much for us, and we were honored to do a little something for these…young Air Force personnel.” 
Board president and retired USAF Col. Harv Shelton added, “This is one of the hardest times in the history of the U.S. to be in the armed forces, and we are happy to do anything we can for these young men.” 
Funds raised from the tournament are used to provide scholarships to high school students enrolled in the Junior Reserve Officer Training Corp. program who plan to attend college. MOAA also purchases scooters for wounded warriors and provides funds to maintain the Hot Springs Village Veterans Memorial. 
Weidert said the troops all “hoped to be invited back again,” and said, “No doubt, they will get invited back again!”
